title: 106_s425
content: The "Food and Medicine for the World Act of 1999" requires congressional approval for any new unilateral agricultural sanction. The "Food and Medicine for the World Act of 1999" mandates congressional approval for new unilateral agricultural sanctions. Definitions for agricultural commodity and program are provided, including programs under the Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act of 1954 and export financing for agricultural commodities. The term "new unilateral agricultural sanction" refers to restrictions imposed by the US on agricultural programs of foreign countries for foreign policy or national security reasons, unless part of a multilateral agreement. A unilateral sanction regarding medicine, medical supplies, or equipment is any trade restriction imposed by the US on a foreign country for foreign policy or national security reasons, unless part of a multilateral agreement. The term "session day of Congress" refers to any day when a House of Congress is in session. The President cannot impose new unilateral agricultural or medical sanctions on a foreign country without submitting a report to Congress and receiving approval through a joint resolution, except in certain circumstances. The President can impose sanctions on a foreign country under specific conditions, including during a declaration of war or national emergency. Sanctions may affect the provision of certain controlled items listed in US laws. Congressional approval through a joint resolution is required within 10 session days after the President's report. The report is then referred to the appropriate committees in Congress for further review and consideration. The House of Representatives and Senate have specific procedures for joint resolutions related to foreign relations. If a joint resolution is not reported by the committee within 30 session days, it will be discharged for further consideration. Floor consideration follows committee reporting. The joint resolution, once discharged for further consideration, can be moved to proceed to consideration by any Member of the respective House. The motion is privileged, not debatable, and not subject to amendment. The motion to reconsider the vote on the joint resolution is not allowed. If the motion to proceed to the consideration of the joint resolution is agreed to, it will remain the unfinished business of the respective House. Debate on the joint resolution is limited to ten hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing it. Amendments, postponements, consideration of other business, or recommittal of the joint resolution are not allowed. After the debate on a joint resolution, a vote on final passage will occur without the possibility of reconsideration. Appeals of rulings related to the resolution's procedure will be decided without debate. Treatment of other house's joint resolution involves specific procedures if one House receives a joint resolution from the other House. This includes not referring the sending House's resolution to a committee in the receiving House and maintaining the same procedure in the receiving House as if no joint resolution had been received, with the final passage vote being conducted as usual. Upon receiving a joint resolution from the other House, the receiving House's action on the resolution originated in that House will apply to the resolution from the other House as well. The final passage vote will be on the joint resolution of the sending House. The subsection is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House, applicable only to the procedure for joint resolutions. It recognizes the constitutional right of each House to change its rules regarding procedures. The subsection allows each House to change its rules for joint resolutions in the same manner and to the same extent as any other rule of that House.
